If the opponent drops the doubled stakes, they lose the game at the current value of the doubling cube. When introducing new players, premade characters can be quite useful, especially for short or oneshot games. But what makes a good premade character in your experience?

Just thinking myself, straightforward gameplay, and a strong easily understood archetype are obvious, but what else? What nuances?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I like my premades with a degree of set dressing customisation. As in: important elements like backstory and where they fit into the story are all played out, but they'll have questions thay fill in blanks:
>what was your relationship with x dead character from your backstory?
Another option is appearance and sex, in games where the sex of the character doesn't matter. Giving a male or female variation of the name is a good call here as I've found names give choice paralysis. People really overthink those. I'm looking to give them a letter when next I do this. Lastly, something to describe their mechanical niche: if the game has tactics/strategy, describe what their toolset is set up to do. If the game is something like delta green where it's more about specialist knowledge, describe what your the character is likely to do in a given situation, i.e. "this character will likely want to perform an autopsy on strange aliens he comes across".
One of the more important aspects though is plot relevance: you're taking away player agency and arguably one of the funner aspects of being a player here. Make it worth it. Do something you otherwise wouldn't be able to do. Use their stories, set up their motivation, have secret information only the character knows. This only becomes more important if it's not an intro game.
